validation_metadata.verification_method: Direct review of Florida Statutes Chapter 119

rights_of_access.statute_citation: Fla. Const. Art. I, § 24; Fla. Stat. § 119.01
rights_of_access.description: Access to public records is a constitutional right in Florida. Every person has a right to inspect or copy any public record, with the right codified in both the Florida Constitution and statutes.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be public records; specific exemptions may apply
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records made or received in connection with official business of any public agency
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Constitutional protection provides stronger foundation than mere statutory right
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite: 'Access to public records is my constitutional right under Fla. Const. Art. I, § 24 and Fla. Stat. § 119.01.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must permit records to be inspected or copied at any reasonable time, under reasonable conditions, and under supervision by the custodian. While no specific deadline is set, 'reasonable time' is generally interpreted as a few days for simple requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: Timeframe depends on request complexity, volume, and agency resources; must be objectively reasonable
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts have found delays of weeks for simple requests unreasonable; complexity justifies longer times
rights_of_access.request_tips: For delays: 'Please explain what makes [timeframe] reasonable under Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(a) for this request. Courts generally require response within days for simple requests.'

rights_of_access.description: If fees are estimated to exceed $200, agencies may require a good faith deposit not exceeding half the estimated cost. Once deposit is paid, the agency must complete the request within a reasonable time.
rights_of_access.conditions: Deposit only if fees exceed $200; cannot exceed 50% of estimate; must complete request after deposit paid
rights_of_access.applies_to: High-cost requests exceeding $200 in estimated fees
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Deposit requirement cannot be used to delay or obstruct access; completion still required within reasonable time
rights_of_access.request_tips: If deposit requested: 'I am willing to pay good faith deposit under Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(a). Please complete request promptly after deposit is received.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies may charge only the actual cost of duplication, which includes the cost of copies, labor, and materials. The actual cost may not include overhead or profit. The first 15 minutes of labor are free.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be actual costs only; no overhead or profit; first 15 minutes labor free; must provide itemized estimate if requested
rights_of_access.applies_to: All requests for copies of public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Many agencies charge 15 cents per page for standard copies; electronic copies typically minimal cost
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge fees: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(a) limits charges to actual duplication costs. Please provide itemized fee breakdown excluding overhead.'

rights_of_access.description: If public records are maintained in electronic format, the custodian must provide access to the electronic records in the medium requested if the agency currently maintains the record in that medium. This includes databases, emails, and digital files.
rights_of_access.conditions: Records must be maintained electronically; agency must currently have records in requested medium
rights_of_access.applies_to: All electronically maintained public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies cannot force requesters to accept paper when electronic format exists
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'These records are maintained electronically. Please provide them in electronic format as required by Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(c).'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies that maintain public records in electronic format must provide remote electronic access to such records when technologically feasible and cost-effective. Many agencies maintain online portals for common record types.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be technologically feasible; must be cost-effective; agency discretion in implementation
rights_of_access.applies_to: Frequently requested electronic records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Check agency website first - many records available through online portals
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'If remote electronic access is available under Fla. Stat. § 119.07(2)(a), please direct me to the online portal.'

rights_of_access.description: All persons have the right to inspect public records free of charge. Fees may only be charged for duplication, not for inspection or search time (beyond the first 15 minutes).
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be during reasonable times; agency may supervise; no inspection fees allowed
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Inspection allows review of records without incurring copying costs
rights_of_access.request_tips: State: 'I request to inspect these records without charge as permitted by Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(a).'

rights_of_access.description: If only a portion of a record is exempt from disclosure, the custodian shall redact the exempt portion and produce the remainder. Partial exemptions do not justify withholding entire documents.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must redact only exempt portions; must produce all non-exempt portions
rights_of_access.applies_to: Records containing both exempt and non-exempt information
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must perform redaction analysis; burden is on agency to justify each redaction
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(e) requires production of all non-exempt portions after redacting exempt content. Please perform segregability review.'

rights_of_access.description: If a request is denied in whole or in part, the custodian must state in writing the basis for the denial, including the specific statutory citation. Generic denials without legal basis are insufficient.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be in writing; must cite specific exemption statute; must explain how exemption applies
rights_of_access.applies_to: All denials or partial denials of records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This ensures transparency in denials and provides foundation for challenge
rights_of_access.request_tips: If denied: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(f) requires written denial with specific statutory citations. Please provide detailed written explanation.'

rights_of_access.description: In litigation to enforce the Public Records Law, the prevailing party may recover reasonable attorney fees and costs. This applies to both requesters challenging denials and agencies defending proper withholdings.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must substantially prevail in litigation; fees awarded at court discretion
rights_of_access.applies_to: Public records litigation under Chapter 119
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Fee shifting makes litigation viable for requesters with meritorious claims
rights_of_access.request_tips: For litigation: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.12 provides for attorney fee recovery if I prevail in compelling production of these records.'

rights_of_access.description: If access is denied, requesters may file a civil action to compel production. Courts may enjoin agencies from withholding records and award damages, attorney fees, and costs to prevailing requesters.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must have been denied access; must file in court with jurisdiction
rights_of_access.applies_to: Improperly withheld public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Mandamus provides judicial enforcement mechanism for access rights
rights_of_access.request_tips: For improper denials: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.11 authorizes court action to compel production and recover fees if records are wrongfully withheld.'

rights_of_access.description: Any person may inspect and copy public records without providing identification or stating the purpose of the request. The right of access does not depend on who is asking or why.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency may request contact information for response purposes but cannot condition access on ID or purpose
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This protects requester privacy and prevents discrimination
rights_of_access.request_tips: If asked for ID/purpose: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.01(1) grants access to any person without requiring identification or statement of purpose.'

rights_of_access.description: The Public Records Law grants access to 'any person' without regard to residency, citizenship, or connection to Florida. Out-of-state and international requesters have equal rights.
rights_of_access.conditions: None - right extends to all persons
rights_of_access.applies_to: All Florida public records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Residency restrictions have been consistently rejected by courts
rights_of_access.request_tips: If residency questioned: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.01(1) grants any person access without residency requirement.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must accept digitally signed requests and cannot require physical presence or wet signatures for records requests. Electronic submission is a valid method of requesting records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Request must otherwise meet statutory requirements; agency must have capacity to receive electronic requests
rights_of_access.applies_to: Electronic submission of public records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Email requests are widely accepted and facilitate rapid submission
rights_of_access.request_tips: For electronic requests: 'This email constitutes a valid public records request under Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(a).'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must make reasonable efforts to provide current and accurate indexes of public records to assist requesters in identifying records. These indexes help requesters make more specific and targeted requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must maintain and make available reasonable indexes; applies to ongoing records management
rights_of_access.applies_to: Public records maintained by Florida agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Well-maintained indexes facilitate access by helping requesters identify specific records
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide any indexes available under Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(k) to help identify responsive records.'

rights_of_access.description: State agencies must designate a public records liaison to assist the public in accessing records. The liaison facilitates communication between requesters and records custodians.
rights_of_access.conditions: Required for state agencies; liaison contact information must be published
rights_of_access.applies_to: Florida state agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Liaison can help navigate complex requests and resolve issues informally
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request assistance: 'Please direct me to your public records liaison designated under Fla. Stat. § 119.0701 for assistance with this request.'

rights_of_access.description: Record custodians have an affirmative duty to protect public records from damage, theft, or destruction, and to make them available for inspection and copying. Custodians cannot obstruct access through negligence or delay.
rights_of_access.conditions: Custodian must exercise reasonable care; must facilitate access
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public record custodians
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Custodians' duties include organizing and maintaining records for efficient access
rights_of_access.request_tips: If obstructed: 'As custodian, you have an affirmative duty under Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1) to facilitate access to public records, not obstruct it.'

rights_of_access.description: Software used to display or access public records must be provided or made available to requesters when necessary to access the records. Proprietary software cannot be a barrier to access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency may charge actual cost of software or provide access through agency equipment; cannot use proprietary formats as barrier
rights_of_access.applies_to: Records requiring specific software for access
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must either convert to accessible format or provide means to access proprietary formats
rights_of_access.request_tips: If proprietary barrier: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.071(2) requires you to provide access despite proprietary format - please convert or provide software access.'

rights_of_access.description: While requests should be reasonably specific, agencies cannot categorically deny requests as 'overbroad' without working with requesters to narrow scope. Agencies must engage in good faith dialogue to facilitate access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency must demonstrate genuine effort to accommodate request; cannot reject without discussion
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requests agencies claim are overbroad or unduly burdensome
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts disfavor agencies that refuse to work with requesters to craft accessible requests
rights_of_access.request_tips: If rejected as overbroad: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.01(1) requires good faith efforts to accommodate requests. Please discuss how we can narrow scope rather than categorically denying.'

rights_of_access.description: While no specific deadline exists for complex requests, indefinite or unreasonable delays violate the Public Records Law. Courts may compel production and award damages for unreasonable delays.
rights_of_access.conditions: Delay must be objectively unreasonable considering request complexity and agency resources
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records requests experiencing significant delays
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: What is reasonable varies by circumstances, but agencies cannot delay indefinitely
rights_of_access.request_tips: For unreasonable delays: 'Fla. Stat. § 119.07(1)(a) requires access within reasonable time. Please explain what makes [X months] reasonable for this request or provide immediate access.'
